{{also|herr}} ==English== ===Etymology=== {{rfe|en}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun|Herrs}} # {{surname|en}} ---- ==German== {{wikipedia|lang=de}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|de|Herre}} {{qualifier|archaic}} * Herꝛ {{qualifier|archaic; sometimes used in fraktur}} ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|goh|de}} {{m|goh|hēriro}}, {{m|goh|hērro||grey, grey-haired}}, the comparative form of {{m|goh|hēr||noble, venerable}} (by analogy with Latin {{m|la|senior||elder}}), from {{etyl|gem-pro|de}} {{m|gem-pro|*hairaz||grey}}. ''(standard usage between strangers)''|inline=1}} ====Usage notes==== * Omitting ''Herr'' (or the female form {{m|de|Frau}}) when addressing a person with their last name is usually perceived as disrespectful, but it is more common when speaking about somebody who is not present, except in formal contexts. However, there may be contextual pitfalls and regional differences, which makes it advisable for learners not to leave out ''Herr'' (and ''Frau''). * When people address each other with their last name, but say {{m|de|du}} to each other, the words ''Herr'' and ''Frau'' are always left out in most regions. In parts of western Germany, however, there is (or was) a system of saying ''du'' and ''Herr (Frau)'' among coworkers. ====Declension==== * The forms {{m|de|Herrn}} and {{m|de|Herren}} were originally simple phonetic/graphic variants. Both were used for the singular and plural inflections. In contemporary standard German they are—usually—distinguished functionally, ''Herrn'' being the inflected singular, ''Herren'' the plural. * With functional split of ''-n/-en'': {{de-decl-noun-m|n|en}} * Without functional split of ''-n/-en'': {{de-decl-noun-m|gs=[[Herrn]], [[Herren]]|ds=[[Herrn]], [[Herren]]|as=[[Herrn]], [[Herren]]|pl=[[Herrn]], [[Herren]]}} ====Derived terms==== {{der-top}} * {{l|de|Dienstherr}} * {{l|de|Empfangsherr}} * {{l|de|Feldherr}} * {{l|de|Freiherr}} * {{l|de|Hausherr}} * {{l|de|Herrenbekleidung}} * {{l|de|Herrenhaus}} * {{l|de|Herrenmensch}} * {{l|de|Herrenmode}} {{der-mid}} * {{l|de|Herrenmoral}} * {{l|de|Herrgott}} * {{l|de|Herrin}} * {{l|de|herrisch}} * {{l|de|herrlich}} * {{l|de|Herrschaft}} * {{l|de|Herr werden}} * {{l|de|Ratsherr}} {{der-bottom}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|de|herrschen}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:de:Titles]] ---- ==Hunsrik== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|hrx|hër}} {{q|Portuguese based orthography}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|hrx|goh|hēriro}}, {{m|goh|hērro}}, the comparative form of {{m|goh|hēr||noble, venerable}} ({{cog|de|hehr}}), by analogy with {{cog|la|senior||elder}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|hrx|/hɛr/}} ===Pronoun=== {{head|hrx|noun|g=m|plural|Herre}} # [[Mr.]], [[mister]], [[sir]] # [[gentleman]] # [[master]], [[lord]], generally denotes that somebody has control over something, either in a generic or in a regal sense # [[Lord]], [[God]] # ''Used as a title of respect that is not translated into English or replaced with'' Sir ===Further reading=== * [http://www.hunsrik.org/Lexi/SearchResult?searchStr=Herr Online Hunsrik Dictionary]
